data.title: Why hasn’t there been an Indiana Jones game like Uncharted/Tomb Raider?
data.meta_description: So I’m watching an Indiana Jones special episode of Mythbusters and it’s making me wonder why we have never got a game like Tomb Raider/Uncharted but with...
data.text:
So I'm watching an Indiana Jones special episode of Mythbusters and it's making me wonder why we have never got a game like Tomb Raider/Uncharted but with Indy instead.

I think it would be amazing.

Is there any possibility we could get one in the future when we get anew Indy film or is there literally no hope? Also is there any cancelled projects I/we don't know about that would've been?

Because the last Indiana Jones game was cancelled and also he usually kills like ten people max and not 900.

Details?

Not everything has to be a murder simulator, think of the puzzles etc you could solve.

Figuring out something similar to the puzzle in the last crusade would be pretty cool.

why pay Spielberg royalties when you can make your own characters?

This right here. I'm sure the Lucasarts license, especially since it's under Disney, would be expensive as fuck now. Better to put that money go towards the game mechanics than a well detailed skin of Harrison Ford.

So I'm watching an Indiana Jones special episode of Mythbusters and it's making me wonder why we have never got a game like Tomb Raider/Uncharted but with Indy instead.

I think it would be amazing.

Is there any possibility we could get one in the future when we get anew Indy film or is there literally no hope? Also is there any cancelled projects I/we don't know about that would've been?

Was going to be a big AAA PS360 game,

got cancelled and they formed the PS2, wii game from what they had

Details?

Not everything has to be a murder simulator, think of the puzzles etc you could solve.

Figuring out something similar to the puzzle in the last crusade would be pretty cool.

That's a tough sell for games that need to hit mass market appeal to be profitable. Making your own characters saves you a fortune and is an easier sell because you can manipulate more without going through companies to "get the okay" for everything you want to do.

Because Tomb Raider is that game except you're not a man in a hat.

Nah, Tomb Raider is not that game at all.

There's like no puzzles or anything in the new games, maybe the old ones sure could be close.

That's a tough sell for games that need to hit mass market appeal to be profitable. Making your own characters saves you a fortune and is an easier sell because you can manipulate more without going through companies to "get the okay" for everything you want to do.

They did the Crystal Skull so they can't be that fussed about Indy like they are Star Wars.

:p

This right here. I'm sure the Lucasarts license, especially since it's under Disney, would be expensive as fuck now. Better to put that money go towards the game mechanics than a well detailed skin of Harrison Ford.

And Disney meddles and limits devs way too much. Besides, licensed games are for the mobile space.

n 2005, LucasArts announced a new Indiana Jones game for next-generation consoles. Originally scheduled for a release in 2007, the game saw constant delays as a result of internal struggles. Due to severe quality issues, it was decided to cancel the project in early 2009. Only externally developed versions for Wii, PS2, DS and PSP saw a release.

When first shown, LucasArts highlighted Indiana Jones as their first game on Xbox 360 and PS3 – with a story written by George Lucas himself. Set in 1939, the player was going to visit locations such as San Francisco as well as "the world's most sacred grounds".

https://www.unseen64.net/2009/08/04/indiana-jones-and-the-staff-of-kings-xbox-360-ps3-cancelled/

what could have been. I really wanted this when i saw it in a magazine way back then.

why pay Spielberg royalties when you can make your own characters?

If Disney's gaming division were still around I think it'd be more likely, but with them moving out of the industry its chance of happening is definitely lower.

n 2005, LucasArts announced a new Indiana Jones game for next-generation consoles. Originally scheduled for a release in 2007, the game saw constant delays as a result of internal struggles. Due to severe quality issues, it was decided to cancel the project in early 2009. Only externally developed versions for Wii, PS2, DS and PSP saw a release.

When first shown, LucasArts highlighted Indiana Jones as their first game on Xbox 360 and PS3 – with a story written by George Lucas himself. Set in 1939, the player was going to visit locations such as San Francisco as well as "the world's most sacred grounds".

https://www.unseen64.net/2009/08/04/indiana-jones-and-the-staff-of-kings-xbox-360-ps3-cancelled/

what could have been. I really wanted this when i saw it in a magazine way back then.

Wow, that looks cool!

It's probably a combination of licensing and Indiana Jones not being a hot commodity at the moment.

Personally I'd like to see a new Indiana Jones game, since I find that time period more interesting than Uncharted's or Tomb Raider's. I'd want it to set itself apart in terms of gameplay too though.

Edit: Oh yeah, I couldn't remember the name, but I played a lot of the Emperor's Tomb on Xbox.

So.... not like Uncharted and Tomb Raider at all, then?

Also, there was this:

I meant more the puzzle/platform aspect from these games and actually going off finding these relics/tombs etc sort of like search through texts in the library/your dads notes to find somewhere to go and off you go, but watch out for Lao Che and his dodgy airplane service lol

Was going to be a big AAA PS360 game,

got cancelled and they formed the PS2, wii game from what they had

Having played through the Wii version, I thought it was a good making for an Indiana Jones story. Gameplay was clunky, but as an Indy fan, liked the story progression, a lot.

If Disney's gaming division were still around I think it'd be more likely, but with them moving out of the industry its chance of happening is definitely lower.

Yeah but remember all the restrictions EA claimed to have with BF2 cosmetics? I'm sure LucasArts will still have a lot of say of what can and can't happen to Indy

I meant more the puzzle/platform aspect from these games and actually going off finding these relics/tombs etc sort of like search through texts in the library/your dads notes to find somewhere to go and off you go, but watch out for Lao Che and his dodgy airplane service lol

That would be cool but the actual "puzzle/platform" sections of those games are pretty rudimentary, making a game that is mostly that would be pretty awful. And I say that as somebody who actually enjoys the new Tomb Raider games.

I understand what you're getting at though, I just think those games aren't really a great base for the type of game you'd want. It would need to be more of a detective or archaeology kind of game, with the action about escaping danger more than it is about fighting tons of dudes.
